title: Unit Fractions in Short Intervals
description: For k ≥ 2, can 1 be expressed as a sum of k distinct unit fractions with denominators in an interval of width (e-1+o(1))k? Croot (2001) proved the answer is yes.

overview.historicalContext: This problem from Erdős-Graham (1980, p.33) asks about representing 1 as a sum of unit fractions with denominators in a short interval. Croot (2001) proved the affirmative answer.
overview.problemStatement: Let k ≥ 2. Is it true that there exists an interval I of width (e-1+o(1))k and integers n₁ < ... < nₖ ∈ I such that 1 = 1/n₁ + ... + 1/nₖ?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the main definitions (unit fraction sums, short interval representations) and prove concrete examples for k=3 and k=4. The Erdős-Graham constant (e-1) ≈ 1.718 is shown to be approximately optimal.

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #286 about unit fractions in short intervals. Croot (2001) proved that for all sufficiently large k, 1 can be expressed as a sum of k unit fractions with denominators in an interval of width at most (e-1+ε)k.
conclusion.implications: This connects the theory of Egyptian fractions to interval constraints, with the constant (e-1) being asymptotically optimal.
openQuestions: What is the smallest k for which width ≤ (e-1)k suffices?
Can explicit constructions be given for all k?
What happens for other target sums besides 1?
